videos.description:

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Welcome to "This Is ADMI",  your inside look into Africa Digital Media Institute.

In this series, we take you behind the scenes of one of Africa‚Äôs leading creative and technical training institutions. Meet our passionate faculty, hear directly from our Head of School, and walk alongside students as they pursue careers in film, animation, music production, design, and more.

At ADMI, education goes beyond theory. Our students learn by doing, using industry-standard equipment and software from day one. With over 500 employer partners and a 100% placement guarantee for diploma programs, we ensure that every graduate leaves not just with skills, but with real-world experience.

Whether you're a prospective student, a parent, a creative professional, or just curious about how we prepare Africa‚Äôs next generation of storytellers, this series will show you exactly what makes ADMI different.

Watch, learn, and get inspired. This is not just school. This is ADMI.

What does it take to teach Gen Z with both truth and tenderness? In this interview, Ciku Munuku opens up about the lessons she‚Äôs learned in the classroom, the hidden strength of today‚Äôs youth, and why second chances matter. Her words are honest, rooted in experience, and deeply human.

She speaks of the young people she teaches with care and clarity. Not just as students, but as whole people. From advocating for mental health to pushing for discipline and heart, she shows how ADMI supports its learners through more than just academics. It's a space where students are seen, guided, and held to a standard that believes in them.

You‚Äôll walk away with insight into what makes ADMI different, what students need most, and why this generation has more potential than they‚Äôre often given credit for. Watch to the end for her three reminders to every young creative stepping into the world.

videos.title: S2: EP18: Equipped For The Workplace - This Is ADMI ft Ciku Munuku
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Career Launchpad was introduced in 2016 to meet a real need. Employers were clear. Many graduates had the right academic skills but lacked the personal attributes that make someone dependable, adaptable, and ready. This course was created to change that. From the first semester, students begin learning how to manage time, relate with others, and understand themselves in a professional world.

Ciku Munuku has led this work since day one. A trained educator with a background in corporate and public relations, she stepped into teaching with curiosity and stayed because it felt like purpose. Her classroom is a space where students not only learn but also unlearn, reflect, and begin to believe they have something to offer. She teaches them to show up, speak well, and prepare with care.

Many students experience Career Launchpad as a turning point. It helps them see themselves differently and understand their potential. They finish ready not just with technical skills but with confidence and practical tools that support their future success.

videos.title: S2: EP17: We Are Competing Globally - This Is ADMI ft Benjamin Waithaka #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Before he ever animated a single scene, he was on his way to the military. But a chance encounter with early 3D software, a friend‚Äôs recommendation, and a visit to a small studio changed everything. In this interview, he shares how animation became a path not just to skill but to purpose.

Now a lecturer, he‚Äôs committed to teaching more than software. He talks about the importance of collaboration across departments, connecting animators with sound designers, and preparing students for real-world work. He stays late to give feedback, follows industry trends closely, and wants each learner to leave as a full, thoughtful professional.

He‚Äôs worked on visualisations for national infrastructure, campaigns for wildlife, global brands, and new 3D screens in Nairobi. But his focus remains on the students. He believes digital content creation will shape the future economy and encourages parents to see creative careers as serious, valuable, and full of potential.

videos.title: S2: EP16: Giving Form To African Stories - This Is ADMI ft Benjamin Waithaka #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Benjamin Waithaka is the Head of Animation and Motion Graphics at ADMI. In this conversation, he shares what it means to teach animation in a fully integrated creative ecosystem. From pre-production to final render, his classes cover every stage of the animation pipeline, blending technical skills with storytelling grounded in African identity. His teaching goes beyond software. It is about shaping visual thinkers who can direct, design, and animate with intention.

He speaks about his student Emanuel, who collaborated with peers to create an African version of a mythological character. That project led to the formation of a working group producing assets for international platforms like Sketchfab. For Benjamin, seeing students take ownership of their creativity and apply it in professional settings is the most fulfilling part of the job. These moments, where the student‚Äôs first creation becomes a lasting memory, are what he lives for.

Benjamin reflects on the role of AI in animation, the importance of staying current, and why Africa needs its own creative trends. His story also includes a surprising personal detail. He nearly joined the military before choosing this path. Now, as an educator and 3D generalist, Benjamin Waithaka is part of a vibrant network of filmmakers, sound engineers, animators, and designers shaping the next generation of African storytellers.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

videos.title: S2: EP15:  I‚Äôm On My Legacy Lap - This Is ADMI ft Sam Mungai #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sam Mungai is the Head of Department for Digital at ADMI and a seasoned photographer and digital marketing lecturer. With decades of experience in media and education, Sam shares how he mentors the next generation of creatives through focused training, industry insights, and honest conversations about what it takes to succeed. His background includes work with Standard Group and teaching at a private university, where he saw firsthand the demand for ADMI‚Äôs practical, skill-based approach.

In this interview, Sam reflects on how digital marketing and traditional marketing continue to work together, and why Gen Z students thrive in specialized learning environments. From photography and graphic design to copywriting and research, he explains why short, intensive programs are often better suited for students who already know what they want. He also shares what excites him most about teaching and the joy of seeing his students win scholarships, get promoted, and find their place in the creative industry.

Whether you are interested in digital marketing, photography, or creative media, this conversation is filled with insights for aspiring professionals. Sam‚Äôs story reminds us that nothing replaces hard work, personal growth is a journey, and mentorship can change lives. Subscribe for more interviews with ADMI faculty and industry experts shaping Africa‚Äôs creative economy.

videos.title: S2: EP14: The World Wants More - This Is ADMI ft Sifa Mutonga #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Sifa Mutonga didn‚Äôt expect to choose ADMI. Years ago, someone she met at a workshop mentioned it, but it wasn‚Äôt her first option. When her dream school said no, she remembered that conversation and decided to give ADMI a chance. That decision changed everything.

From the first report card, something shifted. For the first time, school felt like a place where she could thrive. The classes were structured in a way that made sense to her. The teachers took time to know her. And the environment encouraged her to figure out where she truly belonged in the world of art.

Sifa found herself in the work. She speaks about Mudbox, Maya, and After Effects with growing excitement. What started as a fallback became the place where she gained clarity, confidence, and a deeper love for animation.

videos.title: S2: EP13: Experience Over Everything - This Is ADMI ft Kennedy Wathome
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In this insightful conversation, Kennedy Wathome, a music production lecturer at ADMI, walks us through his unique approach to teaching. From day one, students are introduced to the fundamentals and gradually progress to complex, real-world projects. Whether it‚Äôs producing an album or setting up a live gig, the curriculum mirrors the actual demands of the music industry, step by step.

What makes his classes stand out is the hands-on support he offers. Kennedy takes time to identify where a student is struggling, whether it's technical skills or understanding certain tools. He offers his personal contact, calls for one-on-one sessions, and follows up to ensure each learner feels seen and supported. His priority is to create a space where no one is afraid to ask questions or fail.

Kennedy believes that learning should not only be about acquiring skills, but also about living the experience. At ADMI, students are trained by professionals who are actively working in the field. This tight connection between classroom and career ensures that what‚Äôs taught is relevant and fresh. By the time students graduate, they don‚Äôt just carry a certificate‚Äîthey carry real experience that speaks for itself.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Kennedy Wathome is a music producer and sound engineer who teaches music and sound engineering at ADMI. He came into teaching through a passion for sharing what he practices. His background as both an artist and a producer shapes his approach. Every lesson is built around real studio experience, current trends, and the kind of knowledge students can apply directly.

In this video, Kennedy Wathome shares what excites him about teaching and the moments that stand out in his classroom. He speaks about how discussing industry shifts with students, exploring new techniques, and guiding them through hands-on projects keeps the learning environment active and engaging. He recalls moments of pride when students present work that shows growth, creativity, and ownership.

His sessions are rooted in what is happening in music today. Whether it's a trending song or a new sound design method, Kennedy brings it into the room. He helps students link what they already know with practical skills and encourages them to move from ideas to finished projects. The goal is to build confidence, sharpen their craft, and prepare them to create on their own terms.

This tight connection between classroom and career ensures that what‚Äôs taught is relevant and fresh. By the time students graduate, they don‚Äôt just carry a certificate‚Äîthey carry real experience that speaks for itself.

videos.title: S2: EP9: I Have To Learn The Student First - This Is ADMI ft Manal Omayer #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

Manal Omayer is a lecturer at ADMI and a practicing creative with experience in VR, animation, and conservation storytelling. In this conversation, she shares how she approaches teaching with empathy, adaptability, and a focus on practical skills. Her lessons are shaped by real-world projects and a commitment to making space for different kinds of learners.

She talks about how one-on-one sessions help her understand each student‚Äôs learning style. Whether someone is visual, neurodivergent, or needs more time to grasp a concept, she adjusts her approach to fit their needs. For her, teaching isn‚Äôt about perfection. It‚Äôs about helping students feel confident enough to try, mess up, and try again.

Manal also shares the industry work that informs her classes, from VR exhibitions to projects with National Geographic, Disney, and the BBC. Her hope is that by the time students leave her class, they feel more grounded in their creativity and more open to the process it takes to grow.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 

In this video, ADMI animation lecturer Manal Omayer shares her inspiring journey from childhood sketches to teaching animation in Kenya. Discover how she transitioned from nearly pursuing law to studying animation abroad, and how that path led her to become a passionate educator at the Africa Digital Media Institute (ADMI).

Manal talks about why she believes anyone can learn art with the right fundamentals, the power of creative freedom in education, and how teaching has helped her grow as both an artist and mentor. She explains what makes animation a unique form of filmmaking, how it opens doors to storytelling without limits, and why it‚Äôs about much more than just drawing.

She also shares:

- How she discovered ADMI through a friend
- The value of one-on-one learning in creative courses
- Her recent animation project with the BBC
- Why students don‚Äôt need to be great artists to succeed in animation

Whether you're curious about creative careers in Kenya, passionate about digital media education, or simply love stories about growth, purpose, and art, this interview will leave you inspired.

Hussein Lorot is a Film and TV student at ADMI. In this video, he shares his journey from discovering ADMI at a high school event to finding purpose and direction through film. He talks about the impact of learning from industry professionals, being part of a growing film culture on campus, and how cinematography transformed his understanding of storytelling.

Hussein opens up about the challenges of convincing his family that film is a viable career and how ADMI‚Äôs reputation and hands-on learning helped change that conversation. He reflects on the sense of community, the value of mentorship, and the powerful role African cinema plays in shaping his identity as a filmmaker.

If you're interested in studying film, working with real industry gear, and learning from professionals actively in the field, this video gives you a look into what that experience feels like. Watch to hear Hussein‚Äôs perspective on growth, passion, and building a future in African film.

videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Rayaan Mukhtar shares her journey as a 2D animation student at Africa Digital Media Institute (ADMI), where she found a space to explore her creativity and grow at her own pace. From her first drawing classes to exhibiting her work, each moment helped her build confidence and connect with the storyteller within. The environment gave her permission to be herself and space to learn without pressure.

In this interview, Rayaan speaks about the support she received from her lecturers, the friendships formed on campus, and the quiet joy of learning alongside others. She talks about how ADMI‚Äôs events, diverse student body, and hands-on teaching style helped her feel part of something meaningful. videos.title: S2: EP3: The Art Outlives the Artist - This Is ADMI ft Karumba Ngatia #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Clean sound, professional gear, and industry-ready skills are just the surface. What really matters is what students do with them. In this video, Karumba Ngatia shares how ADMI trains creatives not just to use equipment, but to create work that has impact. Whether it's through a mic, a lens, or a brush, students are challenged to produce art that means something and moves people.

He reflects on how departments collaborate, how students grow through real production timelines, and why it's important to talk to classmates outside your course. Karumba also speaks to the role of parents in a student‚Äôs journey. He encourages families to invest time, support, and belief. Two years of patience after graduation can make all the difference. Not every career starts fast, but steady growth is powerful.

More than anything, Karumba reminds students that what they create has the potential to live beyond them. Every poster, film, or design carries a message, and every message has the power to shift something in someone else. That‚Äôs the responsibility, and the beauty, of being a creative.

videos.title: S2: EP2: The Mindset Behind Great Work - This Is ADMI ft Karumba Ngatia #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

At ADMI, creative training begins with mindset. In this video, faculty member Karumba Ngatia shares how he teaches students to approach their work with full commitment. He encourages them to see their projects as bigger than themselves, as work that could create lasting impact. This mindset helps students give their heart and soul to what they create, whether it‚Äôs a film, a design, or a sound project.

Ngatia explains that students often struggle when they realise what creative work actually involves. Some arrive with a bit of experience, and others come in expecting a simple process. What helps them move forward is a mental reset. He reminds them that they are young and malleable, and uses personal examples to help them reflect on how much they‚Äôve already changed. Once that shift happens, students begin to engage with their work more seriously and with renewed purpose.

The video also highlights the kind of learner who grows fastest at ADMI. Students who enter with open minds and little experience often make the biggest leaps. The faculty, made up of part-time professionals who are active in the industry, support this growth by connecting real creative work to classroom learning. Karumba Ngatia‚Äôs approach offers an honest look into the values that shape creative education at ADMI and how mindset plays a central role in every student‚Äôs journey

videos.description:
Email: info@admi.africa
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In this debut episode, we sit down with Karumba Ngatia, a faculty member at the Africa Digital Media Institute (ADMI), where he teaches in the departments of Sound Engineering and Film. Karumba is an educator and a working creative with a portfolio that includes commercial ads, film work recognized across the continent, and deep mentorship within the classroom.

He shares how a simple tea with an old friend opened the door to his teaching journey, and how showing students real projects keeps his classes engaging. From post-production work for major brands to sound design on the film Click Click Bang, Karumba speaks about his career, his teaching approach, and a former student whose story continues to inspire him.

This episode is grounded in experience, honesty, and a clear commitment to creative excellence in education.

Welcome to "This Is ADMI",  your inside look into Africa Digital Media Institute.

In this series, we take you behind the scenes of one of Africa‚Äôs leading creative and technical training institutions. Meet our passionate faculty, hear directly from our Head of School, and walk alongside students as they pursue careers in film, animation, music production, design, and more.

At ADMI, education goes beyond theory. Our students learn by doing, using industry-standard equipment and software from day one. With over 500 employer partners and a 100% placement guarantee for diploma programs, we ensure that every graduate leaves not just with skills, but with real-world experience.

Whether you're a prospective student, a parent, a creative professional, or just curious about how we prepare Africa‚Äôs next generation of storytellers, this series will show you exactly what makes ADMI different.

Watch, learn, and get inspired. This is not just school. This is ADMI.

Our Head of School Carolyne Sila discusses what makes ADMI a creative space where students can learn, grow, and belong. In this video, she shares how the campus culture is built to support all types of students by offering mentorship, access to resources, and a sense of community. Whether students are outgoing or reserved, they are guided to find their path and explore their full potential.

She also talks about the strong connection between faculty and students. Lecturers are practicing professionals who teach in class and also work with students on real projects. This approach gives learners direct access to industry experience and builds confidence through practical work. videos.title: S1:EP4:  Students Earn While They Learn - This Is ADMI ft Carolyne Sila #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.ac.ke
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581 / (+254) 706 349 696
------------------------------------------------------------------------

In ADMI, students lead the way in every part of the experience. There are active clubs on campus including the Production Club, Music Club, Muslim Club, and Christian Club. Each club is student-led with support from a faculty patron. They organize regular meetings, plan events, and build community.

Students take on real work while still in school. They handle event production for actual clients, take part in paid gigs, and build professional portfolios. Some of the events students have worked on include Nairobi Fashion Week, Miss Universe Kenya, TEDx Nairobi, and Open Cinema. On campus, all production work is handled by students. They manage sound, lighting, filming, live performances, and more. When ADMI needs marketing content, students are often involved in those shoots too.

The alumni network is large and active. Over 25,000 people have been trained, and over 4,000 have gone through the full campus experience. There is a dedicated platform for alumni to upload portfolios and connect with over 450 employer partners. Alumni take part in orientation sessions, speak at parent appreciation events, and stay closely involved with the community.

ADMI Cares is the social impact program that brings together students, faculty, and staff. They collect food, donate clothes, and visit children‚Äôs homes. These activities are done as a team and reflect the spirit of service that runs through the campus.

The environment is inclusive and creative. Students are encouraged to grow in their own way. Whether outgoing or reserved, everyone has a place to learn and build confidence. Faculty members are industry professionals who bring their expertise directly into the classroom.

ADMI‚Äôs core values are ambition, disruption, mission, inspiration, and fun. Every student, staff member, and faculty member is encouraged to live these values daily. The campus is designed to be a space where learning is engaging, creativity is supported, and everyone is welcome.

In ADMI, students lead the way in every part of the experience. There are active clubs on campus including the Production Club, Music Club, Muslim Club, and Christian Club. Each club is student-led with support from a faculty patron. They organize regular meetings, plan events, and build community.

Students take on real work while still in school. They handle event production for actual clients, take part in paid gigs, and build professional portfolios. Some of the events students have worked on include Nairobi Fashion Week, Miss Universe Kenya, TEDx Nairobi, and Open Cinema. On campus, all production work is handled by students. They manage sound, lighting, filming, live performances, and more. When ADMI needs marketing content, students are often involved in those shoots too.

The alumni network is large and active. Over 25,000 people have been trained, and over 4,000 have gone through the full campus experience. There is a dedicated platform for alumni to upload portfolios and connect with over 450 employer partners. Alumni take part in orientation sessions, speak at parent appreciation events, and stay closely involved with the community.

ADMI Cares is the social impact program that brings together students, faculty, and staff. They collect food, donate clothes, and visit children‚Äôs homes. These activities are done as a team and reflect the spirit of service that runs through the campus.

The environment is inclusive and creative. Students are encouraged to grow in their own way. Whether outgoing or reserved, everyone has a place to learn and build confidence. Faculty members are industry professionals who bring their expertise directly into the classroom.

ADMI‚Äôs core values are ambition, disruption, mission, inspiration, and fun. Every student, staff member, and faculty member is encouraged to live these values daily. The campus is designed to be a space where learning is engaging, creativity is supported, and everyone is welcome.

videos.title: S1:EP2: No Student Left Behind - This Is ADMI ft Carolyne Sila #shorts
videos.description:
Email: info@admi.ac.ke
Call/ WhatsApp: (+254) 711 486 581
------------------------------------------------------------------------

In this episode, we expound on how students are supported throughout their academic and creative journey. At ADMI, learners are equipped with essential soft skills through the Career Launchpad program, where they practice communication, write professional emails, build strong CVs, and prepare for interviews. The program includes mock interviews with real HR professionals to help students feel confident in professional spaces.

Students also gain access to AI-powered employability training through our partnership with the Wadhwani Foundation, which introduces AI-led interview simulations and personalized learning tools. In addition to academic support from faculty and access to our digital learning platform, students benefit from one-on-one guidance, timely follow-ups, and structured wellness support through the student programs office and an on-campus counselor.

Every Friday, the campus transforms into a vibrant space for masterclasses, creative showcases, and meaningful conversations. Students also gain real industry exposure by participating in high-profile events like Nairobi Fashion Week, Miss Universe Kenya, and TEDx Nairobi, where they apply their skills in live projects and earn while learning.

ADMI creates a strong sense of belonging, consistency, and structure for every learner. With active student councils, leadership development, and opportunities to collaborate, students grow creatively, professionally, and personally. This episode offers a clear picture of how ADMI nurtures talent, builds character, and prepares students to thrive in today‚Äôs creative economy.

Welcome to "This Is ADMI",  your inside look into Africa Digital Media Institute.

In this series, we take you behind the scenes of one of Africa‚Äôs leading creative and technical training institutions. Meet our passionate faculty, hear directly from our Head of School, and walk alongside students as they pursue careers in film, animation, music production, design, and more.

At ADMI, education goes beyond theory. Our students learn by doing, using industry-standard equipment and software from day one. With over 500 employer partners and a 100% placement guarantee for diploma programs, we ensure that every graduate leaves not just with skills, but with real-world experience.

Whether you're a prospective student, a parent, a creative professional, or just curious about how we prepare Africa‚Äôs next generation of storytellers, this series will show you exactly what makes ADMI different.

videos.description:
Listen in on the thought-provoking discussion with Fadl Al Tarzi, CEO of Nexford University, as he speaks at the launch of the Skills Needs Report, in collaboration with the Federation of Kenya Employers and ADMI (Africa Digital Media Institute). 

From global skills shortages to Africa's unique advantage in its youthful population, Fadl highlights the critical importance of addressing the skills gap in an ever-evolving workforce.

In a rapidly evolving business landscape, employers are facing a significant challenge ‚Äì the struggle to find the right skills for their businesses. videos.title: Unveiling the Talent Dilemma: Skills Survey Report Reveals Enterprises Struggle to Fill Positions
videos.description:
In a groundbreaking collaboration, the Africa Digital Media Institute (ADMI), the Federation of Kenya Employers (FKE), and Nexford University present key findings from the Employer Skills Needs Report. According to the survey, a staggering 20% of enterprises are grappling with the challenge of filling vacant positions. The study, focused on various industries, pinpoints the manufacturing sector as particularly affected, reporting the highest difficulty in recruiting skilled professionals.

videos.title: Simu Nzilani; I Am Future Proof
videos.description:
Nzilani Simu teaches Graphic Design at ADMI and she‚Äôs also a designer, illustrator and lecturer from Nairobi, Kenya. She specializes in branding, infographics, design-thinking, human-centered design, hand lettering, illustration, deck design and she‚Äôs passionate about design for social impact. 

ADMI‚Äôs unique learn, and work model incorporates high-spec technical training, both in and outside the classroom. It consists of four planks ‚Äì industry exposure, work experience, internship and career launchpad. Through this model, our students gain not only knowledge from the classroom, but also soft skills and practical training in their respective industries. Our goal is to ensure that upon graduation, our students have practical skills that give them an edge over other prospects in their field.

videos.title: Vladimir Hernandez Panel Discussion on the Shift From Legacy to Digital Media
videos.description:
Every term, ADMI organizes a Parent's Appreciation Day where we acknowledge and honor the invaluable contributions parents make in the lives of students. 

On our most recent PAD,  we had a panel discussion with Vladimir Hernandez, the Africa Bureau Editor at BBC speaking to our parents on, "The Shift from Legacy to Digital Media; New Options and Opportunities." 

With the convergence of media, technology, and business, Africans can produce and distribute high-quality content for the global market in a way they could not before.

ADMI is on a mission to see 1 million creative technology professionals and entrepreneurs creating world-class content for profit and impact.

videos.description:

Logline: A middle-aged Kenyan man wants to eliminate a cockroach in his kitchen but the cockroach is difficult to catch.‚Äã

Synopsis: Everyone knows not to leave trash lying around as it attracts pests and rodents. Unfortunately for this one middle-aged Kenyan man, he fails to accord to this law and has his filthy kitchen invaded by a single cockroach which he pledges to kill however, what he thought to be a simple task would soon turn into a difficult mission for him.‚Äã

videos.title: Digital Media Incubator - Cohort Compilation
videos.description: The project ‚ÄúCultural and Creative Industries‚Äù is implemented by the GIZ on behalf of the German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) and in cooperation with the Goethe-Institut. It improves employment and income opportunities for creative professionals in six partner countries; Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq, Kenya, Senegal, and South Africa and operates mainly in the music, fashion, design and animation sectors. In addition to promoting the development of entrepreneurial, digital, creative and technical skills through training programmes, the project aims to strengthen the framework conditions and the ecosystem of the cultural and creative industries.

videos.title: ADMI ONLINE - Africa Digital Media Institute is now online.
videos.description:
We‚Äôre making big moves! You can now enjoy the same exceptional education - still global, practical, digital, value-based, and transformational - from anywhere at any time. 
 
We‚Äôre moving to ADMI Online. For the first time ever, our cutting edge courses will be available at the click of a button. Courses will be delivered in flexible 12 week modules designed to fit busy schedules.
 
Our expert educators have also taken their game a little higher, with global certifications in online teaching and blended learning. 
 
Students will receive an education bundle at the low cost of KSh 400/month for all school-related logins. And any hurdles they face during set up, learning and assessments will be overcome with the help of our Student Success Advisors.
 
Through our customized LMS, students can have real-time interaction with their classmates and tutors while staying connected in an isolated world.
 
So will you stay put? Or will you join the ADMI Exodus? Let‚Äôs help you push your career goals forward. 
 
Classes go LIVE starting May 11.

videos.title: ADMI Online - We are now online!
videos.description:
Get started on turning your passion to your profession, on your own terms through ADMI online! We are moving online, and it's better than ever!  Our learn and work model is designed to make sure that you are always creating so you graduate with a strong portfolio and professional confidence. And whether on-campus or online, we ensure that every touchpoint provides you an experience that is global, practical, digital, value-based and transformational. The online courses are designed to be just like face-to-face ones, but better. You use a variety of multimedia learning aids ‚Äì videos, audio-visual clips, webinars, and case studies ‚Äì while also testing your growing skills with hands-on practical assignments. You see all your faculty and classmates in a class where you can raise your hand to ask a question or if feeling a little shy, write it directly in the comments section for the teacher to answer. 

We have also taken up all preventive measures against COVID-19, (CoronaVirus) by ensuring that we maintain social distancing, and thus all classes at the school have been moved online. #StayHome and #StaySafe

videos.title: #CreativeCareers Webinar Series - Marketing & Communications in a Global Crisis
